141492783.review:
I f***ing love this game!

Recommended by a friend of mine, the concept of it caught my interest. Well I finally decided to pick it up, and I honestly can't believe I waited so long. Hellsinger offers something that really isn't out there on the market right now, or is rare. A game that forces you to follow the tempo of the music, and in doing so, mor effective at defeating your enemies.

Now before I go any farther I have to say, if you can't follow the tempo of music (tapping your foot), you might want to pass on this game. While there is graphic interfaces to help with this, I personally ignore them using the tempo of the music itself as my guide to be devastating.

Back to the review, this game is all around well done. Even when you take out the amazing job it does with a combat system around music, you still have a beautiful environment, well designed characters, and a good story, not to mention Troy Baker as the narrator sounds amazing (only one I could see better would have been Sam Elliott). 

I also want to point out the weapons in this game. Their designers already are awesome (I also love the revolvers name, the "hounds" that includes Cerberus). But what I find almost mind blowing is their attributes. They aren't all the same in the sense you can choose what you want and they play the same. They have different styles of play you might say, handling different in relation to using them with the tempo of the music. For instance, the Hellcrow, is like a pair of boomerangs, however, because of how they work, you can't just continuously shoot them. I found myself using them ever 1st and 2nd beat of the tempo (then pause and repeat). To me this was VERY well done by the developers, adding that extra to this game that helps it stand out.

Oh and another cool think, all the music was composed for this game, so you can stream it, without fearing some copyright strike.

Now the game does offer the ability to adjust latency with the audio and visual, however, when I tried to configure this, it actually made it worst. My audio was offset, my video wasn't, and I found myself messing up. Not sure if it's meant to help with the visual cues or what, but for me, I leave it alone.

If you have any curiosity in this game, I would STRONGLY suggest purchasing it. Like I have laid out, it's rather unique in its nature, with not many games that can match. Where they didn't just take this "cool" feature and kind of build a game around it. Instead using it as a foundation and utilizing it to the fullest.

One last thing, piece of advice, you may want to turn down the sfx in the game. In my case, I need to hear the tempo of the music, and sometimes the sfx drown it out, causing me to mess up the tempo.

The most difficult thing in the game is my control of headbanging, as my aim suffers from it.
Basically, you need to shoot and (ideally) reload to the metronome that is partially matching the music. If you don't shoot in time - the damage is significantly lower. I have changed in the setting the color of a "good" hit, to make it clearer. From white to purple. 

Very interesting genre! Not sure I'd be a regular in it, but for the price - definitely recommend to try. In 2 hours I've got significantly better, so it's a skill issue quick to acquire. From "how the fuck they expect me to do that!?" to nailing 4 challenges in a row from the first try, after only 2 hours of playing. 

If the game is too difficult and you don't want to suffer the timing shots, you can disable the metronome and all the hits will be counted as "good" in the game settings. As simple as that. Enjoy anyway!

141318727.review:
You're not buying a game, you're paying for an addiction.
Mostly unique in its genre this is Doom on steroids.

Story:
You're a voiceless demon who's sole objective is to go down the pits of hell and beat the final boss that will give you your voice back. Or at least, that's all you know.
You'll learn more about what's going in between stages by listening to exposition from your friendly skull who's voiced by Troy Baker.
The plot here's only purpose is to drive you forward from one stage to another and it's not the reason you're buying this game for.

Gameplay:
The story is pretty much a tutorial where you'll acquire all the weapons and learn how to adapt to the game's rules by performing actions according to the right beats of the songs in each stage.
Each song has different beats and each weapon works differently with the purpose of throwing you off balance.
Now there's a learning curve but by sticking to it you'll get better and better and once you've got the gist you'll just wanna play for the hell of it.
The gun-play is good, there are some execution animations but not that amazing. Killing demons on the beat is the gratification this comes with. On top of that if you sync your attacks to the beat not only does it deal more damage but at max combo the vocals kick in and make the experience even more intense. 

Soundtracks:
The soundtracks vary from good to very good to freaking awesome - as it should.
There's no variety here unless you purchase the DLC. It's metal, from start to finish but it's good.
Combined with the gameplay you get the fun of it.

Downside:
Graphics and stage layout isn't something that aim to impress.
The length of the game's awfully short as you can only play through a couple of stages and  it gets repetitive fast. You get locked in a room, have to clear out multiple waves of enemies, then go to the next room. Do it 5 more times before you get to the boss.
And speaking of bosses, they are a big shame since they're all the same -copy paste from one stage to the other instead of using unique demons for each stage. They do change their attack pattern but nothing more than that.
You do not have the option to implement your own custom songs in the game which I believe it's one of its greatest flaws and drawbacks. Freedom to the player is always a win.

Overall:
Despite its downsides you will want to replay stages, try out more songs and complete special challenges for powers that offer you a better benefit on higher difficulties.
This is probably the best first person rhythm shooter and it doesn’t punish you if you miss all of your shots. You still can play and enjoy this audiovisual masterpiece.
However I don't recommend this at full price unless you're a die-hard fan of metal and doom.
Get it on sale, preferably for 15 bucks.
And if you happen to enjoy the experience, buy the DLC for the extra songs.

141204144.review:
Summary:
Great game (3.5/5 stars) for metal enjoyers, who like bashing some demons to the rhythm of a double pedal bass. But it isn't without it's flaws. If you can grab this for less than 20 bucks, it's worth it.

Pros:
+ Awesome soundtrack for metalheads. Best in the whole industry
+ Power fantasy, as you aggressively bash your way through the hells
+ Gameplay is solid and everything plays to the rhythm of the song
+ Decent variety of guns, although there could be more like a rocket launcher or two swords
+ Replay value in challenges, leaderboards and difficulties 
Cons:
- Story is basically irrelevant, even though cutscenes and voice acting is great
- The story is over in 2 hours if you're good
- There's basically 2 bosses in the story. 1 that you kill like 8 times and the last boss, which was very annoying. You get hit by random stuff and the feedback to what hit you is non-existent
- I bought a DLC that gave me new songs. I don't know what to play to get them, as they weren't present in the story
- The level design is boring. Basically every level consists of several closed arenas, where enemies keep spawning until you've killed them all. This is not very exciting. It would be much cooler to run through long hallways and places and just keep moving forward while destroying everything in the path.
- The variety of mobs. There's literally 10 mobs in the game and a few of them are the same but different colour. They're not very exciting and it gets repetitive real quick.

141193963.review:
This game obviously has an amazing soundtrack, but it also feels great to play- you can easily enter a flow state once you get into the rhythm. There are 8 main levels, which felt sufficient to me. Not every game has to be 60+ hours of content and I appreciate when games don't overstay their welcome. That being said, I think there's some great replayability here simply because it's so fun to slaughter demons to the beat. 

As a side note, the narration from your skull companion Paz (voiced by the talented Troy Baker) adds some nice levity and is just a joy to listen to. I also really liked his surprisingly wholesome and encouraging voice lines when you die! The demo is what sold me, so definitely give it a go if you're into metal or Doom.

140978678.review:
[h1]Woah. Pretty metal, i'd say[/h1]

I did try games in the same "flavour", like shooters with metal music, but this is different.
I love metal music but i am very picky, and while the music in-game is not all perfect, i'd say it's pretty good, with few songs being really great.
Art is beautiful, so are the desolate levels in Hell. It's all a very special kind of beautiful.
Plenty weapons to have fun with, each with their unique ability (Ultimate), and you even get a fucking skull that shoots fireballs. 

I bought this today, and i played it without too many breaks, i now finished it and writing this review.

I would say it's a bit pricey. While the game is great, and has a perfect amounth of length, not very long to get boring, not too short to make you crave more, it kinda feels a bit off price-wise, but that's probably because they also have to pay the musicians.

All in all, it's a great game, with a very chaotic atmosphere, reminds me of Doom and Quake very much, and that's a very good thing in my book.

While you cannot add your custom music just from few clicks, the devs enabled some modding. It's a very complicated process that i am too old for, sadly, but maybe in the future there will be an easier way (Installing F Mod Studio is fine, but all that importing songs in another software and locking the BPM and all that is very finicky)  

I strongly recommend this. It's just great. It's a game where demons are preparing for their boss battle with YOU, and they end up dying like ants.

139967848.review:
In short: this game is awesome.
In long: This was my first ever rhythm shooter, directly coming off of Ghostrunner and doom eternal. 
It was a bit tricky at first to get the hang of it, but after about two levels following the music just came natural. 
I'm now 60+ hours into the game, played it 3 times over, got all the DLCs, modded a few songs and I still can't get enough.
Speaking of modding: Funcom provides a free music modding bundle running in F-mod, and fully supports modding, including tutorials on their Youtube channel. And the fact that it's allegedly a passion project makes it even better.

Minor setbacks are that I often get stuck on objects, but that might just be from me playing like a maniac, constantly flying across the maps at Mach 10. Also the in-game latency calibration could provide a way to slide into negative values, but there's a workaround for that, so no big deal.

Overall, this game is awesome rhythm practice (Which I appreciate as a guitarist). 
It got me to try out vocals for the first time, including screaming, and I can't stop myself from doing stuff on beat while listening to any music anywhere.
The OST is an absolute masterpiece involving some of my favorite artists and some that I didn't know about before that I now love. Just a shame that it's not officially on Spotify at the moment.
The story and lore is not on the level of something like Hollow Knight(bad comparison, I know) but it's good enough for the game, and there are even some interesting twists thrown in.

The narration, Oh the narration. The story is told from the perspective of Paz, the flaming skull you use as a weapon. The southern accent fits perfectly, and there are some lines that genuinely got me chuckling so hard, it messed up my beat matching.

10/10 game for any fans of metal or fps games. And if you love both: BUY THIS GAME RIGHT NOW.

139611569.review:
It's about getting the "feel," for it. More than just the beat (though that is a core mechanic). Took me a while, I generally suck at this kind of thing.

Only one tip I would give that really helped me get the "feel," was after the tutorial, and perhaps a few deaths in Voke you may be thinking, Arrg crrssp I can't get the hang of this. I was anyway,, if you are good at this kind of thing/game may not be necessary.
So, After a while dieing and getting basic mechanics down, head to the accessability menu and change the color of one or more bright white squares. I used green instead of default white for "good." Headshot of course remains red. One more in the top section, I used blue instead of white default for, crap can't remember the name but it's the second one, beat maybe? Leave Hud at 100% opacity (default) and for me at least this really made it come alive and feel natural.

Not for every one, and maybe change just one or any combo or leave default. All I can say is what I wrote above helped me enjoy the game much more. It felt great! It may be useful, but I think, for me at least, it wouldn't have helped at the very first few plays. It was by chance because I had that idea after failing to kill the first boss, in Voke too many times (on medium or goat difficulty)  I thought about if I had done that at first and quickly realized it may have confused me more, or something else, but default colours first IMHO, are best. But it's a guess based on my cruddy forgetting which button to press, timing off, missing slaughters blah blah blah. That's just my take, and seeing as I suck generally taking my advice may lead to fits of rage or mental breakdown.
 
Oh, yeah, the game. I love it. It is just a lot of fun, great action set to catching the beat. I would strongly recommend it! For talentless players like me the first few sessions were pretty irritating, but now it feels more natural. Just in very violently pleasant way, with heavy metal fully integrated and a main part of the game.
That just sounds like a very good thing to me, literally, and generally!!

138847707.review:
[h1]Who Would've Thought Killing Demons In Sync With Rhythms Could Be So Dopamine-inducing?[/h1]

Rhythm game was never my type, but if you integrate it with shooting, that is a different story. The first game of this sub-genre I tried was BPM. It`s a fun game, yet something about it just didn`t click with me. So I try the subject of the review - Metal: Hellsinger, and I can confidently say that this game single-handedly ignite the spark of interest for the sub-genre for me. The rhythmic gameplay, the theme, and bonus challenges are really well-done. I highly recommend this game for those also looking to jump into the rhythmic shooters sub-genre.

[h1]Thing I Like About Metal: Hellsinger:[/h1]

[b]Combat, Arsenal, Music, EVERYTHING[/b]
Everything about this game is amazing.
→[b]Combat[/b]: I cannot stress enough how great it feels to shoot a gun in sync with rhythm of background music. This feature alone instills a certain flow of gameplay which is hard to recreate in other boomer shooters. Everything must be on beat. Bullets deal much more damage on beat. Shooting on beat grants more points. And music hypes up progressively as you do things on beat. All of this good traits form together a strong core gameplay loop that can easily pulls you in for hours.
→[b]Arsenal[/b]: Besides actions, Metal: Hellsinger also introduces 7 hellish armaments that each has its own unique flow of rhythm. Since all the weapons performs equally strong on beat, players can just choose whichever suits their playstyle. My favorite weapons of mass destruction are The Hounds and Hellcorw. Dual-wielding revolvers is something I can never pass up. Shooting these two bad boys on beat never gets old, and the dopamine never stops coming. Hellcrow, on the other hand, bounces off me at first. It`s weird beat and boomerang style really are my thing, until I dive in, giving it a shot. This weapon is actually a great multi-kill and crowd-control tools.
→[b]Music[/b]: Metal, as the music genre, is inherently compatible with extreme violence. Like Doom, Metal: Hellsinger has several blood-pumping soundtracks that merge wonderfully with on beat gameplay and demon-killing. One feature I have mentioned above is that as you build up the Fury meter, music gets progressively more hype-up. At maximum 16x, vocals start kicking in, and THAT is when the gameplay tension and immersion elevate to the utmost hype.

[h1]Things I Dislike About Metal: Hellsinger:[/h1]

[b]Minor Complaints[/b]
→Bosses are kinda boring considering all of them are basically the same model.
→Late game arena sections could be hard to dodge projectiles and shoot on beat at the same time.

中文小簡評

137730120.review:
Just finished the game. Even though game is short, it's pretty exhausting and has some replay value BUT, gameplay is pretty simple without much to offer, most enjoyable part was over the top metal tracks. The artist contributed to this game are all part of bands I listened for tens of hours as in past and that alone made me hyped for the game. Though it was a bit disappointing experience in the end.

[b]Pros[/b]
+ Soundtracks
+ Good graphics and performance

[b]Neutral[/b]
= Story is neither bad or good, it's there to fill a void but don't expect much. Narrative is good though.
= Cutscenes have some good art style, but they are not great. Mostly it feels like seeing same thing over and over again.
= Game takes away the music as you fail and rewards you with extra instrument layers as you succeed. I think it makes everything too focused on the music and almost not care about the combat part, I might as well play guitar hero. Though I think some might like it this way so, neutral.

[b]Cons[/b]
- Game gets old fast:
-- There is small pool of enemies, one boss that spawns at the end of each level and one more final boss(2 in total).
-- 4 Unlockable weapons(+1 with DLC, I don't have it); close range, long range, AOE, infinite ammo with a slightly harder shooting mechanic. Nothing exciting.
-- You don't have much chance to get familiar with boomerang-like weapon, other weapons are pretty simple so it's just one weapon you'll probably never use. It's still effective if you can't get the timing perfect(throwing without waiting to get both back) so it's not a big deal.
-- Challenge stages keeps repeating themselves mostly
---Overall it's pretty linear experience.---
- You have to switch to skull and keep shooting to keep your multiplayer from decaying, it's makes game exhausting and makes me rush through one battle to another. I didn't have any chance to look around and explore the world, I was like tunnel visioned through the whole game.

Unfortunately this looks like negative review more than anything and it breaks my hearth. Personally I prefer BPM over and over again, which is much small production and much simpler game, but it's much more enjoyable for me. I also liked the lack of vocals in BPM. This game is too focused on music part and gameplay aspects falls too short in my opinion. 

Still, by no means it's not an enjoyable game, I enjoyed it very much but I don't think I'm going back playing this game again. Playing this game makes me want to install BPM. I think they should ditch the narrative driven campaign and just let us shoot stuff on beat in fun and unique ways.

137432466.review:
What I liked:
* The fury mechanic with layered music is probably the best thing I've seen to reward good gameplay, and I always felt encouraged to play the best I could to keep the awesome music going.
* The fighting-to-the-beat mechanics really helped this feel like a good fast-paced shooter. The gameplay loop from arena to arena with waves of enemies let me mow down monsters to a banger of a song. 
* The music in every level was top-notch and I enjoyed them all immensely.

What I didn't like:
* The game felt too short. I'm not one to 100% and I don't care about pushing stats on a leaderboard of people I don't know, so I finished the game in about 4 hours. That includes all the levels, and the minigames that I cared about. 
* On the minigames, the rewards were boons that never really felt impactful to the game, so on the one hand it was easy to play the ones I wanted, but on the other I wasn't incentivized to play the ones I didn't.
* The boss arenas played very differently from the level arenas, and it was jarring at times. Apart from the final boss, they felt like cut-and-paste copies with different bullet-hell mechanics not present in the rest of the game, with scripted minion swarm intermissions that never felt as good as the levels. The final boss was completely different from every boss before it, but it also felt like the devs took all the ideas they had for the game and dumped them into a single encounter. The only way to practice the boss was to play the boss. That wouldn't be an issue except that restarting meant playing through the entire level again. The boss mechanics being different meant weapon choices for the level and weapon choices for the bosses varied, which ultimately lead to a less than satisfying experience.

Overall:
I enjoyed the majority of my time spent playing this game. I feel that $30 for a 4 hour game is a bit pricey, but if someone has the cash and wants to hear some great metal for a few hours it's a good buy.

137286430.review:
Satisfying, fluid combat complimented by a very impressive soundtrack. A must-play if you're into metal.

Properly calibrating your latency to find what feels best is *crucial* to enjoying Hellsinger. It might take a bit, but I found the game far more engaging once I spent some time on the calibration.

The challenges are similar to those in Doom (2016), in that you have to complete a goal in X time for Y buff. The buffs you get for completing challenges are minimal at the start, but by the end of the game they can shape the way you look at encounters. You're encouraged to pick the weapons and buffs that augment and accentuate your playstyle.

The game isn't very long - I got all of the achievements in under 9 hours - but it has decent replay value bolstered by arcade mechanics.

I also found it relatively easy to learn as someone that plays almost exclusively rhythm games and no shooters. I've only played on Goat but I'm decent enough to hear the vocals at least half of the time. The story is also easy to understand and interesting to make you follow along with it as well. 137223374.review:
I was going to write a negative review but upon further reflection, it's still gonna be a positive one.

TL;DR: Play BPM: Bullets Per Minute first and if you crave something new, try this one but with lowered expectations.

Metal: Hellsinger is by all means a fun game but I'd say it's also extremely underwhelming. The most glaring issue simply is the lack of content and underdeveloped rhythm mechanic. In every department you are going to notice shortcomings and lack of diversity: The environments pretty much all look the same, the story is the same thing happening 8 times in a row, you have the same boss fight 8 times in a row, weapons all feel very similar, unending waves of the same enemy types over and over again, soundtrack - even if an absolute curated list of bangers - blends together. The only thing the different difficulties change is how much damage you take, how big the enemy health bar is, and how many enemies there are. The enemies don't become smarter or faster, it's just more of them and they become very, very tanky. There's one new enemy on the highest difficulty but it's just an advanced version of another regular enemy and it also only appears rarely. Not to forget, I don't know who in their right mind would think that waiting for a boss to go through 20 invincibility phases during a boss fight would be fun, half of the time you are just waiting for the boss to be fucking done with transforming and I'm not exaggerating.
Now regarding the rhythm mechanic - it's simple and underdeveloped: You shoot, reload, or dash on time, only on full beats, that's it. No interesting rhythms, no faster timings, just always slow full beats. You might think to yourself that this is plenty enough when you also have to play a FPS simultaneously and you are right to think so, for the first 10 minutes that is. After that, the game is the same from start to finish. For that reason, I'm telling you to play BPM: Bullets Per Minute first. Not only does it have amazing weapon and item variety, but it builds rhythm into the game in an interesting way as well. In addition, BPM has great replay value due to it being a rogue-like and having multiple, game-changing characters to play as. Metal: Hellsinger on the other hand is just really the same being served to you time after time.

So in conclusion, you will have fun with MH but your money will be better invested in BPM.

137129505.review:
Phenomenal concept for a game, but it's miles away from its potential.

The single biggest flaw this game has is that its rhythm game aspect doesn't change to match a song's tempo. Each song has a set "metronome" behind it that corresponds with its average beats per minute. You're supposed to match all your shots and kills up to this metronome regardless of how the song might change. Almost every song in the game has multiple tempo changes, but this metronome never slows or speeds up to match. It's extremely jarring to be on a kill streak only to have the song reach a quiet bridge section that makes you completely lose your timing.

While I like metal music, and think most of the songs are great both on their own, and to accompany a demon shooter, I can't help but shake the feeling I would be better off playing this game without the sound on. The game gives a visual on-screen queue next to your aim reticle that's there to help you match up to the aforementioned metronome. It's easier to keep with this constant, never changing rhythm without having a song playing that might distract you into deviating from it.

If anyone has ever played a Guitar Hero/Rock Band game, you'll remember the calibration settings. This game has that as well, but I found it extremely difficult to get right. I looked around on the internet a bit, and found that this is a common issue a lot of players have. I can't say exactly why this is, but I've found different songs feel better with different calibrations, even though I'm using the exact same pair of headphones each time.

Outside of the rhythm stuff, it has other conventional gameplay issues.

I was disappointed in the similarity of all the boss fights. Excluding the final boss, they're almost identical in design, even if the arenas and move-sets differ slightly. They all even play to the exact same song. I get the desire to have a "boss theme" for your game, but that type of repetition doesn't lend itself well to a game who's primary mechanic focuses on music.

I also frequently felt like I was searching for more stuff to kill to keep my streaks going. The levels in the game are mostly made-up of a string of loosely connected battle arenas (a la Doom 2016/Eternal), and you're locked into each arena until the scripted number of spawns are slain. The problem is that the spawns don't continue until every single enemy (no matter how small) has been picked off from the previous spawn, and the AI is also prone to get stuck on walls. As a result, it wasn't uncommon for me to finish a wave of monsters and then lose my streak looking around the arena for scrub #999 who had his toe caught on a staircase somewhere.

The other single worst contributor to its pacing issues are the shield-wielding enemies. They were harder and more annoying than any other enemy in the entire rest of the game, and it introduces you to them fairly early on. Their shields are too large too shoot around without a good amount of precision that many guns don't have (you have to shoot their left hand), hitting their shields doesn't count as a "hit" so it's easy to lose your streaks, and they aren't particularly easy to strafe around in some environments either. I can't tell you the number of times one of these guys would linger around after everything else was dead because I just couldn't kill it with a reasonable amount of effort. It was a great way to completely destroy some otherwise amazing action sequences, as my streak and music would die during all the extra seconds I would have to spend trying to jump around to get behind one of these guys' shields.


Despite some of these glaring flaws, this is still a good, fun game. You will still enjoy it if you like metal music and can get past the feeling of handicapping yourself by leaving the music on. I'm giving it some tough love here because I WANT it to succeed and be better. I want Hellsinger 2 someday, and I want them to get the music matching right to make it the true rhythm shooter everyone dreamed this could be. I fully support what they're trying to do here, and what they have is still a lot of fun, it just has a lot of missed potential.

Giving 30 Dollars for a 5 hour experience is pretty... Eh. Obviously this is void if you are planning to 100% the game or plan on playing the game a lot (Like Speedrunning). If you are planning for a one-time playthrough, i recommend getting the game on sale.

- Good weapon choices.

Cons:

136893742.review:
What if when the Doom music kicks in, so did you?
In what I guess is just becoming its own genre, Hellsinger is in the company of BPM: Bullets per Minute and Hi-Fi Rush as an excellent rhythm/action hybrid. As someone who deeply enjoyed BPM, this was just the fix I needed. The gameplay is a bit more forgiving than BPM, but oooh... Just as satisfying.
The story actually surprised me in that there is one. Narrated by Troy Baker as Paz, a talking skull with a smooth accent and no memory, the story managed to do juuust enough to transcend the bog-standard "Kill demons, kill more demons, then finally kill Satan" plot it first appears to be. Even when I thought that was all it would be, the sexy narration and charmingly simple cutscenes were still kinda doing it for me.
Not that the game even needs much in story, as the pick-up-and-game style feels more at home in an arcade than a theater. Here, gameplay and soundtrack are king, and Hellsinger knows it.
The music rocks, as should be no surprise, though I hope you like metal, as the soundtrack only barely transcends the genre of its namesake. Though if metal isn't your cup of tea and you bought the game with a demon glaring over the title "METAL: HELLSINGER", I do question your purchasing wisdom.
Lucky for me, I do at least somewhat enjoy a thumping jam, and this game brings it. I'm no metalhead, but really anything with a solid beat would still be fun, and there a few songs in the soundtrack that even I as a filthy casual greatly enjoyed.

The only negative notes I have are glorified nitpicks.

The guns are pretty hit and miss.
The first four work great. You start with a sword and a simple semi-automatic projectile weapon to learn the beat matching mechanics, and they each have unique strengths enough to remain relevant for most of the game. Next are a shotgun and akimbo revolvers. These are awesome. Satisfying, effective and intuitive.
The last two (in the base game at least, I haven't tried the DLC) I feel very different about.
First is something that seems like it should be good. A long range precision explosive crossbow. But it doesn't deal that much damage, so its use is more for mopping up hoards of smaller weaker enemies. But it only has two shots before needing a reload, which is the longest reload in the game (and is one of the few actions that feels off-beat, unless you nail the active reload). At the damage it does, it needed to have a lot more shots to be useful, or if you're dead set on only two, please give it some oomph. This crossbow had all the reload speed and explosive power of a water balloon launcher.
The last weapon is a pair of boomerangs. Which aren't quite as terrible as they at least deal decent damage and can cut through multiple enemies. However, they are fairly close range and are easily surpassed in high single target damage by the revolvers or shotgun. Their flight path is too difficult to track to use in any way beyond occasional accidental extra corpses near your intended target.
So yeah, bit of a bummer that after a certain point there's really no reason to try any other weapons beyond tried and true shotgun and revolvers.

The challenge trials are fine I guess. Some feel pretty impossible, or arbitrarily testing skills that have little to do with the primary gameplay loop, but eh, better than nothing I guess.

Don't let those two tiny little vestigial nubs hanging off this gem like skin tags hiding under the armpit of a supermodel stop you from taking it on the town. You'll only be in a position to notice if you've already gotten close enough that you're committed, and it's easy to overlook anyway. 

TL;DR
Fun gameplay, 70% good weapons, rockin' soundtrack make great game. If you liked BPM, you'll like this. If you liked Hi-Fi Rush, but wish it were more like Doom, you'll really like this one.

136781103.review:
Loved the rhythm game/fps mix. Highly recommend this.

Be aware the 4.5 hours was enough for me to play through the game on normal, plus the DLC level, and get all the achievements. It's pretty short.

Pros: 
* Awesome soundtrack.
* Shooting feels solid 
* When you get into an actual rhythm, the game is a ton of fun. I'm not even a huge metal fan, but this all just works. 
* Movement feels really good
* Weapon variety isn't bad.
* Optional challenge levels were also mostly fun to play through, even though a couple of them had me a little frustrated
* Short and sweet, but higher difficulties are available, and I will probably go through and give the hardest difficulty a shot

Cons:
* Probably a bit too short, though I think the game as-is doesn't really have the legs for a much longer campaign
* Story is nonsense. After sitting through the dialog for the first two levels, I skipped the rest. It doesn't really matter, so if you play feel free to skip it. I still loved the game without listening to the story.
* While there's plenty of weapon variety, it felt like the pistols were by far the best. I used them through pretty much the whole game except against the shield enemies where I pulled out the sword. I also found them and the shotgun the easiest to keep rhythm with, but the pistols have the range/ammo advantage.
* Bosses kinda sucked and were the worst part of the game. They're all the same model with slightly different movesets. The game would have been better without them IMO. They didn't ruin the game by any means, and didn't make me want to quit, but they're definitely the game's weakest aspect.
* The DLC was pretty good, but the DLC weapon felt pretty awkward. 

Overall though, I absolutely loved this and played through the game and got all achievements in one day. Definitely worth the $30 in my book, though be prepared for a short title. I'm a little upset I waited so long to play this one.

136709613.review:
It's kinda just a 'big' budget experiment and it's not really good tbh.

The sound design is good, the music is fine too, but outside of that it doesn't do anything particularly well for me to recommend any of it.

The combat ranges from "200 cannon fodder enemies get one hit by you" to "haha heres 400 projectiles and area damage with no clear telegraphing so youll take damage alright" all the while you gotta stay on beat and generally move around the arena. It's a lot at once thrown at you with very sloppy visuals.
Like 90% of this game is orangey-brown. Enemies, the environment, everything. It quickly becomes very mushy and eh i am not a fan.

Kinda spoilery? The bosses are like all the same with one annoying thing switching out between encounters. Shoot the boss, kill the weak enemies that waste your time, then shoot the boss some more. Incredible. 
The level of danger from each boss is very arbitrary? some you just kinda run in circles without taking damage and thats it, some have random invisible-feeling attacks that come from outside your field of view that chunk you for a third of your health, and nope not fun.

In general suffers from the same issues as BPM, just because the concept of "DOOM, but youre forced to shoot with the beat of the music that plays" is fundamentally just very flawed? 
And worse than in BPM, except for the sword, sub-divisions of the 4/4 beat just do not exist at all in this game. Which for a rhythm game... is very disappointing. If I wanna shoot 3 8ths in a row, i should be able to do that with proper timing, rather than be forced to do 3 4th beats. It's a super arbitrary restriction that just makes the game worse.

Story exists in this. The narration is... very... mediocre? It's not bad, not good, it's very predictable, generally uninteresting, but not bad enough for me to skip it, so i end up sitting through something i have no investment in with the cutscenes. 

the funny numbers:
audio 8/10
gameplay: 5/10
story: 3/10
overall enjoyment: 4/10

Can't recommend.

136498217.review:
Metal: Hellsinger is a glorious fusion of boomer shooters and rhythm games. It works surprisingly well, and within no time you'll be headbanging along to the soundtrack while blasting demons. It is a very difficult game in parts; I played the game on Beast difficulty and had to restart the last level several times, along with some others. Also some of the torment trials were incredibly difficult. The weapon selection is diverse, and help you to blast apart the large variety of enemies.
It is pure metal violence and I loved every second of it. Honestly, the soundtrack alone is worth the pricetag.. and you get a free journey of pure dopamine along with it. The combat is unbelievably satisfying, the story is interesting enough and the graphics are far better than I expected.

Note that most people report playing the main story in only around 4 hours, but I spent longer due to replaying some levels and playing through the torments (challenge trials to unlock this game's equivalent of Doom 2016's runes). I will say that it is definitely worth it regardless, the quality is insane, nothing is padded out for the sake of it.

Once I finished the main story, I bought the DLC and replayed a couple levels with the new songs, gun and outfit. That's worth it too imo - both songs work so well in this game; especially Will's.

Played entirely on linux, no issues there - I believe steam deck support is fine too.

136369669.review:
[h1]NOT TRASH.[/h1]

[b]Metal: Hellsinger[/b] is a first-person shooter rhythm game developed by the Outsiders and published by Funcom. Combining fast-paced action with timing and rhythm creates a unique and exciting experience.

[table]
[tr]
[th]🟩 Pros[/th]
[th]🟥 Cons[/th][/tr]
[td]
Soundtrack
Immersion
Gameplay
[/td]
[td]Story, Short[/td][/table]

[h2] \m/ [/h2]

The concept is simple and rarely seen at this production level. The game's premise is simple, you are in Hell and must fight a horde of demons to find your voice again stolen by the Underlord himself. While the story starts as an exciting concept, it sadly is a complete afterthought. Unmemorable at best, there is little to do throughout the game about character development despite all the interesting elements you encounter throughout your playthrough.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2959616033

You are not grabbing Metal: Hellsinger for its story; you are here because it's a Rhythm game, and it's achieving that exceptionally well. You need to follow the tempo set by both visual and sound cues. On top of that, to attain peak headbanging status, you will have to ensure that you don't lose the combos you are building. Each level has its particular soundtrack that keeps building up the more you kill, dodge, reload, and jump on the beat to let the vocals be heard finally. I don't think there's anything more satisfying than the drums connecting with a properly timed reload+headshot

You will also get to use finishers ala Doom to regain lost health, and ammunitions are infinite so that you can focus on the action. The controls are very intuitive and easy to take on, and we must applaud the developers for the accessibility features included in the game that are going to make sure that everyone gets to enjoy the game.

It would be impossible to review this game without talking about the soundtrack. It is one of the best I've heard in a video game. Two Feathers, a studio focused on video game music, delivered a phenomenal product with the help of famous Metal singers ranging from Arch Enemy, Dark Tranquility to Trivium, Lamb of God etc. The singers also did an outstanding job on each track, and the music is seamlessly integrated into the gameplay; the result is an incredibly immersive experience.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2959616083

Graphically speaking, the themes are exactly what you would expect from hell, dark, gothic, and satanic, with each demon being different and identifiable. 

Sadly, the game is short, and the level design is all the same level after level. The boss fights especially, it’s all the same enemy with little variations, and even though there are some challenges to extend the game's length, it’s not quite that. Though, it must be said that the game is infinitely replayable if you want to compete for leaderboards. Indeed you can compare your score with other players, improve on it and keep headbanging.

Finally, Metal: Hellsingers is a fun and unique game that will appeal to both metal fans and rhythm gamers, and while it is short, the spectacular soundtrack and gameplay make up for it.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2959618213

136190052.review:
tl;dr review: The game is super fun to play minus a few snags and length. Outside of that I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

Metal: Hellsinger is a first person shooter where pretty much everything is dictated by the rhythm of the soundtrack. And to start somewhere I'll talk about the soundtrack. It's so damn good. If you're into heavy metal music you'll absolutely love the OST. And even if you're not there's still some great tracks in this.

Now moving onto the gameplay itself as mentioned before the game runs off of the rhythm/beat of the soundtrack. If you match if with your dashes you can chain them together, or doing more damage with your guns, reloading faster, and even being able to perform finishing moves. This all sounds good and when you're moving around in perfect sync then it feels amazing. But when you lose the beat and fumble to recover it feels really shitty to try and get back to where you were. Granted the game has a suite of difficulty options as well as an accessibility option to make sure that you're always on beat, which is nice

As a quick aside shout outs to the dev team for giving the player a whole host of tools to customize how they want to play the game. Fully remappable controls, changing the color of UI elements and many other options to tweak to the player's content.

Though I do have address the elephant in the room, and that is it's length. It took me about 7 hours to get all the achievements in the game. And although while there are still other things to do such as getting the Coat of Arms (weapons skins), it wouldn't add that much to the runtime. And this can be even far less if you're either really good at the game or just go from beginning to end and don't bother with the extra content. That said if you're looking to chase high scores and top leaderboards then this game has immense replay value in that regard. 

But there's no getting around the fact that at retail price it's $30 and even half off it's $15. Truly I believe that everyone that worked on this game deserves that $30 (and frankly more) due to the sheer quality, it'll undoubtedly be a hard sell for those that want their games to be meaty in content. Doubly so when they can find games around the same price or cheaper and provide bare minimum double the amount of playtime. Though it does gain the benefit of getting to do everything that it wants without overstaying it's welcome.

135984441.review:
A mix between DOOM and BPM that ends up being worse than either in its own field. You can't get into the flow of doom clone gameplay because you have to constantly watch the beat but so many things are constantly changing that it's hard to keep the beat. DOOM solved the first issue by allowing you to play at your own rhythm. Sure you have to play fast if you want to live but you aren't locked to a single rhythm like in Hellsinger. BPM solved the latter issue by having consistency; your actions are locked to the beat, enemy attacks are locked to the beat, even the limited cutscenes (if you can even call boss intro screens cutscenes) don't force you out of the beat unlike Metal Hellsinger's. Back to Hellsinger, the game tries its best to make you do poorly. Want to listen to the full song because you're having trouble keeping on the beat? Too bad, you have to stay perfectly on beat if you want to make the music sound good.

Overall the game just feels like the devs tried to combine DOOM and BPM without understanding what made either of them good. If you want a good boomer shooter, go play doom. If you want a good rhythm shooter, go play BPM.

135912135.review:
I want to like this game more than i currently do but there is just too many gripes i have with it.


Gripe 1

There is too much shit to look out for.

This game combines a shooter game and a rhythm game into one. (Yeah no shit get to the point) Shooters are trying to make you use your brain by:

-Making you look at your surroundings

-Making you look at how many enemies there are

-Analyzing your best approach from a positional standpoint

-Aiming and shooting


Metal Hellsinger now adds:

-A rhythm game with tight timing that you HAVE TO LAND or else you are not going to deal any damage

-A quick reload system that also works with the rythm game

-Having to count how many bullets you hit your enemies with so you can use your execute because that's one of 2 ways to regain health

-A Hit streak system that activates "Boons" which can make a drastic difference in how you approach a situation as one of them makes your execution kills an AOE attack which deals massive damage/usually kills everything.

-Bullet Hell attacks


and with all that you have an absolute clusterfuck of a game that just overwhelms your brain to the point where most people will just throw it away and go to the next.

This game can be/is VERY stressful if you don't scale down the difficulty



Gripe 2

You essentially only have 2 Bosses in the game with the same boss being recycled over and over and over.

We have 8 levels, and the same Boss appears in ALL 8? Are you serious? The final boss of the game is absolute shit btw. You can't beat that thing unless you learn it's attack patterns which is already hard as none of the attacks are telegraphed in a way that make it obvious or at least hint that you should dodge.



Gripe 3

Levels are Boring. 

If you'd ask me which level is Gehenna and which one is Nihil based on pictures, memories or descriptions alone I couldn't tell you. They all look so identical and play so similar that none of them end up having an actual Identity of their own.



Gripe 4

There is one level where they take away one of your weapons. That level is constantly crashing for me. I had to go through that shitshow 6 times until it finally let me beat the boss. I had hoped that it was just my older hardware (I'm still running a GTX970) but even turning down the graphics and everything to it's lowest made the level crash for seemingly no good reason. It's the only level where crashes occure.


Don't get me wrong i still really like this game despite of it's flaws but it could be a lot better.

135769688.review:
The game on the surface looks like Doom Eternal crossed with a rhythm game. And well, it's exactly that, and it executes that idea flawlessly! The guns feel great, the movement feels great, and the soundtrack is absolutely stacked with talent. I was worried the rhythm component would feel forced, but it actually complements the aggressive playstyle. 

If I had to nitpick:

135572158.review:
Metal: Hellsinger is a solid and well rounded demon shooter and rhythm game hybrid. The team behind it clearly have a lot of love and passion for this game and it shows. Often compared to DOOM, rightfully so, does not fall short in hitting that satisfying feeling you're looking for in these types of shooters. M:H is by no means braindead easy, and can be challenging at times. There is a clear learning curve and skill gap in learning the timings for reloading and counting how many shots you can get in safely. The game is short, but very replayable. The game is starving for some DLC, which is actually a good thing. 

My only gripes with the games are as follows;

- Some guns feel WAY better than others. I felt almost 0 reason to switch off my preferred weapon, and often found myself switching back, even after unlocking a new gun designed for the level.

- The bosses (very very light spoilers) [spoiler] are the same at the end of every level minus the last, and it takes away from a lot of the badass designs and anticipation towards the ends of the levels.[/spoiler] 

- The songs kind of all blend together, while they're all enjoyable the game would benefit from different metal subgenres.

Overall, if you LOVE DOOM, or the hell/demon shooter aesthetics pick up this game, and is an easy buy on sale.

135565539.review:
Metal: Hellsinger is what you get if you made an entire game revolve around the gore nest mechanic from DOOM 2016, and put some beat matching behind it. 

In short: it's fine. It's playable, it's good fun at times, and most of the songs go hard enough that, besides the obvious drive to try and keep the max combo multiplier going, you're also driven to keep it high enough that you can hear the backing track in its glorious entirety. The problem is that Metal: Hellsinger clearly designed itself around the new DOOM games and, consequently, suffers from constant nagging comparisons to that franchise - whereas DOOM's soundtrack ducks and swells with the chaotic action and extremely brief moments of peace around you, M:H's backing track stays (mostly) the same throughout the level, and indeed the whole game; whereas the glory kills in DOOM instill a sense of liberating violence, the 'slaughters' in M:H feel somewhat lifeless and weak; whereas the legions of hell in DOOM come in many shapes and sizes with all kinds of interesting mechanics and weak points, the enemies of M:H start off as somewhat uninspiring and only grow more tedious with exposure (I was particularly unimpressed with [spoiler]the final boss of each level being the same enemy with a slightly different gimmick each time[/spoiler]); whereas there is a constant back-and-forth in DOOM as you juggle your health and ammunition against those legions, you have infinite ammunition in M:H, health tends not to be much of a problem, and when it does become a problem there's a lot of conveniently placed wall crystals to heal from, which kinda defeats the point of having the slaughters/glory kills rewarding you with health in the first place.

Indeed, perhaps the biggest comparison-problem with M:H is that that back-and-forth in DOOM has an internal rhythm of itself - jump, dash, shoot, switch weapon, glory kill, jump, dash, grenade, rip, tear, etc etc; it's a masterpiece of game design that this internal rhythm is both set and felt by the player simultaneously, affording an experience that is completely unmatched in singleplayer FPS. In an act bordering on sacrilege, Metal: Hellsinger takes that experience, cuts out the most universally loved aspect of it, and instead forces the player to follow an external rhythm of their own design.

I really don't want to make it sound like i'm railing on this game for no reason, or that I didn't enjoy it - I did, I think it's worth your time, and while I think it has flaws it's still a solid game with a great soundtrack. It's just very difficult not to compare it to what it was clearly inspired by, especially where the design philosophy falls well short of its inspirations.

135538951.review:
REALLY good. Worth all the praise it gets. Just a couple of complaints:

1) The Coats of Arms are bloody awful. They're dingy lil' collectibles, each one hidden in ONE obscure corner of the map and there's no way to tell where any of them are. In a game that works very damn well without exploration and functions as a great linear rhythm shooter, these things are an active detriment to the experience. Secrets and collectables are nice when the game isn't punishing you for not progressing or keeping to the rhythm and I have better things to do than rub my nose on every single corner for a specific doodad. And I have to do this ONCE for each difficulty level?! That is beyond parody.

2) The bosses are cool but it's very annoying when I have to start the whole level again when I die to the boss. I get that a rhythm game means I have to play the song to its end but each boss has their own song separate from the level. What's more, I often died trying to learn the boss' attack patterns, so I have to play through the entire stage again to get back to them, only I still haven't committed them to muscle memory and all that time back in the stage has made me forget again. This wouldn't be so bad if the bullet hell-esque mechanics of each boss didn't mean that I get blindsided in the first person perspective all too often and am often left in complete bewilderment as to what killed me. The final boss in particular just melted me all the time with alarming speed. I just wish the bosses were their own stages.

But aside from those two glaring issues, this is a fantastic game. What I really appreciate is that there's an actual story with actual characters with actual interactions and goals in play. I like a bloodfest as much as anyone else but I really need some context in my games and <u>Metal: Hellsinger</u> provides in abundance. I enjoyed how Paz revered the Unknown and how the Red Judge actually interacted with her subjects and how she schemed. There's depth here that a lot of retro-aspiring FPSes feel is beneath them. Yes, I care about the story; we can have good story and gameplay in accordance. New Blood, this is aimed at you.

Although I don't like inconclusive conclusions; I sincerely hope there actually is a sequel to round out the plot. Sadly, I am sceptical; <u>Beyond Good and Evil</u> has ruined me. Please prove me wrong.

So... Lets expand upon this. I gave it a no recommendation... Because a neutral option does not exists. But also due to the fact that it has recieved an inflated rating. Even though past titles exists that does what this does already, and in several cases... Does it better.

Ive played alot of rhytm based game, and alot of hi-intensity games the likes of later Doom Titles, Beat Saber, Ghostrunner, BPM, Succubus etc. I found all of those alternative titles to do what this game does better. Each in their own way.
And even if we only take the music into account. Some pretty nice tracks are found in both Doom Eternal and (Guardians of the Galaxy; granted thats an entirely different genre)

This game is a case of average. The jack of alot (not all) of trades, master of none. 

Should you play it... Maybe? Depends. Not my decision to make. Its a good game in on of its own. But in the broad spectrum of available titles. Better can be found. Does'nt mean its bad, just that better can be had. Take of that, what you will.

Enjoy either way.

135281708.review:
I'd recommend the game whether or not it was on sale. I'm not a huge metal fan, but know plenty of people who are and like the music enough to be able to keep the beat and have fun with the title. I'm only 3 hours in at the moment and have been really enjoying the challenge, visuals and just uniqueness of a game that combines Rhythm and FPS. That aside the game fails in a few different areas. 

- Weapons, throughout the game you get a few different weapons. Some are cool, but only like 2 of the weapons out of the 6 actually carry the beat well. 
- The rest can throw you off at times, since there are no sounds for the them after their original hit. Outside of that, the weapons just seem poorly optimized. Some weapons seem to do crazy damage, while others seem to do barely any. 
- Enemies could be better too, the list just keeps growing so levels towards the end just have everything. I'm to the 3rd to last level and the "newest" thing I've seen was a enemy unit. The boss has been the same boss every level, which might make sense for the story but is truthfully a little lame.
- Difficulty is kinda weird. I'm fairly good at first person shooters and aim for a positive K/D Ratio in most FPS titles; Halo, COD, Valorant, etc. And this game was actually killing me pretty often, but more just from what I'd view as kind of bad design more so than it just being "Difficult" like a Souls-esque game. 
- In this game, you have like the same base health and weapons act the same throughout the entirety of the game, from what I've seen. And I really feel like the game would gain A LOT from even having Stats to upgrade health or maybe upgradable  weapons, since it does get slightly stale. 

Overall, as I said in the first paragraph. I would recommend this game to others. It's a fun game. A great introduction to Rhythm games for me; and a title with great music and graphics, I just wish it was more polished.

I haven't had this much fun in a shooter since Painkiller. This game is a fantastic piece of art.

That said, be aware of what exactly are you getting. It's a pure rhythm shooter, and that aspect bends everything else towards it. The bestiary is rather small with a limited move set (which is a plus for me TBH). Same goes for bosses - there are mechanics to them, but very simplistic. Levels are impressive visually, but on a smaller side with rather simple arenas. Weapons are fun, but basic (mostly), and there are only 6 of them. Every piece of complexity and difficulty here comes from songs, which become faster and more demanding as you progress. And each boss arena switches from the main track of the level, throwing you off beat.

And the game is short. 8 levels. On one hand, it doesn't overstay its welcome with how intense it's to play. On the other, I simply want more.

134923031.review:
I feel like we were waiting for a long time for a game that combined rhythm and combat together well, and as is usually the case, in recent years all the games have come along at once. Metal: Hellsinger wasn't the first, but in my eyes it's definitely one of the best.

This is essentially like playing DOOM but you have to stay on beat and be stylish otherwise you won't get to hear the best parts of the absolutely incredible metal soundtrack.

The game also supports (with some work) custom songs which is neat, though I wish there was some sort of feature where customs songs could be easily shared, as it stands it's a bit of a gimmicky method.

Overall, I strongly recommend for not only that soundtrack and challenging but fair combat, but also the variety of weapons, perks, bonus missions and a neat story to go along with it.

134864478.review:
Like Beats Per Minute, Metal: Hellsinger isn't as great as it could be, but the FPS + rhythm combination is still fun. 

The largest annoyance in the game is weapon switching - ideally you'd have only two primary weapons to swap, and you'd be able to use Paz with RMB. Instead Paz is its own weapon slot, and you're also given a sword for some reason. So in a bullet hell / beat situation, you end up futzing way too much with selecting the right weapon instead of shooting things.

The "aspects" of the Judge are disappointing. Ideally we'd instead have separate boss designs with more distinct boss mechanics. Instead we get (essentially) one recycled boss. The worst part of the boss fights is when the boss becomes immaterial.... oftentimes you're just waiting around for no reason, which kills the game's momentum. It's also discouraging to see so many arena battles with ads during boss fights, since arena battles were all you were doing before the boss.

Last complaint is - if you're going to spend so much time on storytelling, don't do it all through narration. I mean, the story's not great, but the retrospective narrative format makes it even more of a slog.

The music's great, though, and unlocking vocals only at 16x fury is a nice touch. The weapons feel good and the enemy designs are great (although the shield enemy can oftentimes be at an angle where you don't have a shot, so you waste time and fury re-positioning, which dampens the game's flow). The finishing melee moves for health a la Doom are also always satisfying (especially for aerial finishers).

134720055.review:
More than anything, this game feels like a proof of concept with a single redeeming factor: its music selection.

For starters, the combat is rudimentary. All but one enemy type are dealt with in the same way and don't require any particular tactics or specific weapons, which does not encourage people to play around with different approaches. The movement is stock standard: there is a double jump and a dash, neither being used all that much for combat purposes. Lastly, the special abilities are underwhelming and somehow detract from the intended on-the-beat experience.

For the game set in hell, the levels and enemies are extremely uninspired. There is only a handful of enemy types and, again, they don't require any specific technique to be taken down. As for the bosses, there are practically only two: the one that gets recycled X times and the final boss. Both of them shoot projectiles and spawn minions - nothing more, nothing less.

I haven't followed the story as I found the first few cutscenes extremely boring, which made me skip all the following cutscenes.

All in all, considering the Metal: Hellsinger's price tag, the amount of content is severely limited. I finished it in four hours, which includes spending some time on the optional challenges. Paired with the things mentioned above, I feel this game is not worth your time (but maybe OST is).

134691414.review:
An absolute masterclass in Rhythm Action design, along with the likes of BPM, Crypt of the Necrodancer/Cadence of Hyrule, and now Hi Fi Rush (released after Hellsinger.)
As a note, it looks as if I may be "reviewing" this game with little time in it, but on the contrary I've completed the game 100% on game pass, then purchased on console, and now purchased on Steam.
This game is just that good, (if this genre clicks with you.)
I say that, but at the same time, I TRULY believe that anyone who enjoys the hard rock/metal genre and at least a base level enjoyment of shooters will absolutely adore this game. 

I think the best way to describe Hellsinger, among other's in it's masterclass, is just utterly satisfying. Shooting, movement, and synchronization to the music come together to form an incredibly cathartic loop of "Easy to learn, difficult to master."

The game features multiple difficulty settings and tweaks, allowing for players of all skill levels (and rhythmic capabilities) to jump in and feel like they are being given a fair shake at the game.

But once you REALLY get it, and you can just jump in and stack up flawless combos up to the hundreds while being accompanied by the glorious soundtrack that The Outsiders have put together for this game, crunching bones and popping skulls right in line with the heavy thump of the kick drum, is unlike most things you can experience in gaming. 

If anything of what I've said here peaks your interest, or if you watch a trailer and even THINK "That looks pretty cool," then yes. It is. And you should play it. It absolutely slaps.

134502046.review:
Metal Hellsinger is a first person shooter where the player is a demon trying to escape from hell. The unique gameplay twist is that you have to fire your guns in time to the beat of heavy metal music to build up your damage multiplier, allowing you to kill enemies quickly.

[h1]The Good[/h1]

•	Feels like an old school shooter where the movement is fast, there are lots of enemies in each encounter, and you have to always be moving to avoid taking damage.

•	The beat matching gameplay mechanic is fun. I found that I didn’t really have to look at the on screen timing indicator, I was able to use my ears to track the beat, so my eyes could focus on aiming at the demons.

•	There are four main weapons including dual pistols, shotgun, explosive crossbow and dual throwing axes. I mostly used the shotgun because its click click boom click click boom firing speed is a close match to the music beat, while the pistols’ longer effective range makes them more useful against bosses.

•	A couple of other mechanics add a tactical element to the combat. Successful attacks build up your weapon’s ultimate meter, allowing you to use a special attack powerful enough to one hit kill most enemies, which I would save for the more dangerous demons. And when an enemy is near death, you can press a button to quickly fly over and execute them, causing them to drop shards which restore your health (similar to the modern Doom games).

•	I played on the medium (“goat”) difficulty because I wasn’t sure how tricky the beat matching mechanic would be. Regular encounters can get intense on the later levels, while the bosses are quite challenging because of their bullet hell style attacks.

•	I didn’t have any problems with bugs, crashes or framerate. Controls are fully rebindable and work great with mouse and keyboard.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]

•	The game is incredibly short, as I completed it in just 3.4 hours. It seems like the developers intend the player to replay the same levels over and over again chasing high scores for the leaderboards, which isn’t really what I’m looking for in a single player FPS, although I suppose I’ll have to do it to salvage some value for money.

[h1]The Recommendation[/h1]

If you like your shooters fast and your music loud, Metal Hellsinger is definitely the game for you. Its just a massive shame that the game is so short, and because of this I can only recommend it on a deep sale.

Unknown is a dumb name.

134305405.review:
Love at first sight (first play?), this game has been living rent free in my head for two months and I don't think it's planning on moving out anytime soon + the game gets extra points for having a cool demon lady as a protagonist.

The gameplay is really satisfying and it only gets better once you get the hang of staying on beat and unlock some extra modifiers through the torment missions. Some hitboxes (both yours and the enemies) can feel a bit off at times, causing you to get hit by attacks that look like they shouldn't have landed, but also the reverse where attacks that go right through you just decide to not register. It's not bad enough where it makes the game frustrating to play (but I guess that also depends on how easily you get frustrated), but it can definitely be noticeable. 

The game isn't incredibly long, with 8 missions that last about 20-ish minutes each you can play through the story in about 4 hours. The game does have replay value for those that want to hunt for cosmetics or highscores though, and personally I've replayed the levels a lot simply to listen to specific songs again. And my god are the songs good, I was a bit concerned I'd get sick of them eventually by replaying them too many times, but with 30 hours played and even more time spent listening to them on my free time, there isn't a single one that's gotten old yet. There's also modding tools that let you add custom songs to the game, although the process of making said mods can be a bit daunting even with the guides the devs have provided. 

So anyway, buy the game. Maybe wait for a sale if you're going in just for a single playthrough, but if you think it looks like something you'd enjoy for a little longer then it's well worth it even at full price.

134296898.review:
If Doom Eternal was a Rhythm Shooter featuring legendary Metal Vocalists!

Doomlike gameplay but a little more chill on the arsenal side of things (you dont need 12 hotkeys for your guns and other equipment). Great metal tracks exclusive to this game and nice cohesive artstyle. The "rhythm shooter" aspect of the game is very well implemented, most weapons feel very intuitive and the combat loop is fun overall.

134060830.review:
Metal: Hellsinger is a thumping and growling story of love and rebellion armed with a lovely video game shotgun, a pair of revolvers, and fire-spitting skull with a nice and relaxing voice. Think... Tetris Effect + Doom... or what if Guitar Hero was an FPS? Mind you that this game really lives and dies by what you hear, as what you see is pretty far from the latest and greatest triple A-tier. The graphics are more than serviceable, but the soundtrack and audio in general... ohhhh ho ho ho... what a treat!

So, to wrap this review up:
-For a certain kind of gamer, this is an ballet of metal music and guns that puts them in a flow-state.
-For a certain other kind of a gamer, this is a lukewarm corridor shooter that punishes for not shooting in rhythm.

Consider which kind of a gamer you are and make the purchase decision based on that. Or the demo, if it is still available.

It's short and... Lacking, for lack of a better word. And short. And it lacks something or other. Because it is short. And it lacks a certain [i]je ne sais quoi[/i]. It being short is not a huge detriment, but, still... There's something lacking in there...

If the above sounds stupid, you won't like Hellsinger. If you feel the vibe and the rhythm in the loqaucious absurdity, Hellsinger is your game.

It's 6-7 hours tops if you're good with rhythmic clicking, more if you want all the achievements. You get to click at 60-80 bpm (no adjustment to the songs' tempo) and listen to Jesse "Cole Cassidy" McCree as the narrator. Weapons are not too varied, enemies are samey (only one of those requires a change of approach) and the bosses are sorely disappointing (down with the "boss is immune for over half the fight and feeds you a stream of trash mobs so you can recover health" mechanic already!),

But there's a semi-decent metal album attached to the game, so that's nice if you're into stuff like that.

I love Metal, I love first-person shooters and I love Milton's Paradise Lost, but I don't love this game. I don't hate it, but somehow it feels to me like less than the sum of its parts. Again, this is an entirely subjective opinion, but the questionable level design, limited enemy variety, and that one goddamn recycled boss fight make it difficult for me to recommend this.

A lot of pre-release buzz has been made about the soundtrack, but I don't find any of the track memorable and the lukewarm performances by the guest Metal celebrities fail to impress. I get it, it's a rhythm game and the beat has to be fun and predictable. I'm certainly not expecting folks to shoot to Archspire or Meshuggah. Still, I can't help but think that 4/4 makes for some boring-ass Metal!

Also, what's the deal with those entirely unnecessary, slow-as-hell expository cutscenes? I mean honestly, did you just buy a game called 'Metal: Hellsinger' because you were expecting a dialogue-driven narrative masterpiece that will tug at your heartstrings, or because you just wanted to shoot some fucking demons to a beat? Yeah, my point exactly.

Good overall use of Unity, though!

132260266.review:
A beat-matching FPS where the player goes from one arena to the next exterminating demons to the sounds of growling metal. Occasionally a girl does chime in with some mellifluous vocals, and Serj Tankian comes on for the final boss fight. The arenas lock up after entering them until cleared, and monsters spawn in waves out of thin air in predetermined points in the arena. Levels are essentially corridors, and there is no platforming.

The shooting is pretty simple, but every weapon has an ultimate attack. Some of these can help get some breathing room when overwhelmed. Weapons include a sword; skull with a low-damage regular ranged attack with an ability to charge it up and freeze enemies in place; a customary shotgun; a set of revolvers; an area-of-effect crossbow; and a set of scythes. There is no BFG-equivalent here.

You have your basic, weak and numerous melee feeder enemies; a couple of larger and tougher melee enemies who can quickly close the distance; and a selection of ranged enemies - grounded or airborne - who have telegraphed hitscan or projectile-based attacks with dumb or homing projectiles. Some have an area of-effect attack to prevent the player from getting too close and staying there. Every level culminates in a boss fight with a big flying head which fires projectiles and spawns waves of enemies.

In addition to the regular levels, there are "Torments" - time-limited challenges which, if completed, award the player with bonuses like faster Ultimate attack meter build-up or room-for-error allowance to perform a few actions off-beat without losing the hit-streak multiplier. These arenas can also serve as practice.

Trying the harder difficulties with spongier enemies, no player revives, and stricter rhythmic window made me realise I have no idea what a "beat" actually is. Basic movement and jumping off-beat is allowed unlike in The Crypt of the Necrodancer. However, shooting off-beat deals almost no damage, and having to lay it into a single enemy while getting swarmed by the others can get rather disheartening (regular enemies do not seem to have remaining health indicators to help decide if an enemy should be "focused"). Getting one of the achievements involves passing a level without a single action off-beat, even evasive dashes, and that seems impossible at this reviewer's skill-level. If requirements for beat-matching become too much, it can be turned off completely in accessibility settings.

On "Goat" - the medium difficulty - the game took around eight hours to play through the story and all "Torments". One thing to note here - since one of the "Torments" requires weakening enemies first to perform executions on them, it seems a higher difficulty has to be selected for it, as the enemies have less health on lower ones and die before an execution can be performed on them (alternatively, the game recommends selecting a weaker weapon, but, to my untrained eye, that seemed less efficient). I find the game length to be plenty to show off what is on offer here.

131977690.review:
Game is good, I wouldn't say "overwhelmingly good" but it's still good and if you like rhythm games and don't mind a bit of metal music I will recommend

Quick overview
Basically this is BPM with a more heavy metal + vocals, and a slightly different combat system. I think the soundtrack is a bit too much screaming metal than what I'm into.
And I will not say "This game is better than BPM" because both games have good things about each.

Pros: Setting, graphics, gameplay. I'm satisfied with this. The attack on beat is forgiving as you still attack it's just weaker if you make a mistake.
Voice acting for Pak is great. I'm not sure why they chose that voice but it's a nice decision. Story is very well written, it's pretty simple, but enough for myself to enjoy.
Weapons are good and have reload bonuses for timing. I have favorites and it's nice to change up and use different things.
Also a pro: the final song with Serj.

Cons:
Enemies do not all attack on the beat. I don't know why but I'm moving and shooting to the beat and some enemies do attack on beat (I think) but the ones that fire whenever they want are harder to fight, causing you to have to quickly do a off beat maneuver, jump or dash. This might not be a problem for everyone but it is a mild annoyance.

I would like it if there are no enemies then the combo meter just pauses. If you're wanting to keep the combo meter high you have to have the skull out and always clicking to fire it to keep the combo going. I don't agree with this. Why not "any" weapon? Why only the skull? And while on this topic, why does it have to keep going between battle rooms? Like when exploring or such.

Minor complaint: I would like a glory kill with the other weapons. When you hit E you dash forward and pull out the sword to finish people off. I would've liked to do it with the other weapons but this is just a nitpick and not a real problem.

Con, but this is personal because of my taste in music so you don't have to consider this as fully part of my review score.
I said it above, I really like the music but I don't like most of the vocals. It's fully a personal opinion, but I honestly cannot stand playing the game more than like 30 minutes at a time because of the screaming lyrics.
Exception: Serj did a great job, and the female voice accompaniments for stage 2 and 3 are also really good. (I actually was looking up some of them).
