131610691.review:
Fun game with a kickass soundtrack. It lacks in some aspects but overall I definitely recommend it. Record says I got 11.8 hours but I was AFK with the game open a few times, so I think I got about 10 hours out of the game. I only played in the highest difficulty available from the start (you unlock another difficulty level after finishing the game but I didn't feel like playing in that mode tbh). I only played in the lowest difficulty to cheese two awful achivements (Pazifist and Not shaken, nor stirred) 

Overall, a 7/10 for me and I certainly recommend it even at full price. Breakdown below:

What I enjoyed:

- Really damn good music, they got some awesome singers for the soundtrack. The band Two Feathers really composed some fantastic stuff. I liked 4 songs the most (This Devastation, Stygia, Dissolution and No Tomorrow), but the whole OST is awesome. Wish I could buy it but so far I haven't seen a way to do so.
- Good performance and graphics.
- I really appreciate the fact that this game includes an audio/video latency calibration tool. However, it suggested me values that I found just wrong for my PC (g-sync monitor with good g2g latency and an usb-c audio interface with low latency). I was unable to get Perfect reliably until I decided to leave everything in 0 ms instead of the values provided by the tool. That fixed the rhythm issue for me and improved my flow with the game a lot.
- Great combo of rhythm game + FPS. The devs did great with the mechanics, such as the weapon and how the reload works, the fury mechanic and how the song changes depending on how well you're doing,  and keeping it simple with a three tier scoring (perfect, good, miss) for each input.
- Pretty cool aesthetics overall in both enemies and hells design.
- Alright variety of enemies with nice mechanics. Though I wish there had been more types of [spoiler] angels [/spoiler] for making the game more interesting on the later levels.
- Good voice acting (MC doesn't talk, tho).

My annoyances with this game:

- Repetitive bosses. I wish it had had more unique mechanics to each fight than [spoiler] bullet hell with a few variations + wave of enemies[/spoiler].
- Levels could've been a bit less linear, maybe have two or three different paths.
- Repetitive execution animations...if there had been some a few more variants it'd have been nice.
- Not a fan of the "animated" drawings used for the story telling. I figure they were on a tight budget so I understand that, but still, I didn't like them much
- Ran into a few bugs, mostly getting stuck in some enviroment props and having to restart (happend twice I think). Also the execution animation of the tall elites sometimes glitched and the enemy's legs clipped through the floor. This happened more than 10 times probably.
- Can't quick restart torments (challenges you complete to unlock perks). After failing some very challenging torments, having to sit a few seconds through the defeat animation plus a progress bar filling got old. It was faster to press ESC and restart than sitting through that, especially when I knew I had messed up and wouldn't win that run.
- They added collectibles in a post release update to unlock skins for the weapons, but really, I don't understand why the devs thought it'd be a good idea to spread them in 3 difficulty levels. I wish that if I played in the highest difficulty, I'd be able to obtain them all at once, not having to play the same level at least 3 times - assuming I was able to find them in one run. Also I pretty much never found one on my own, only thanks to guides I was able to get a few, but by then I just gave up and decided to enjoy the game than looking obsessively to every single nook and cranny trying to get find one. In other words, it was a frustrating addition that took me out of the gameplay if Itried to find them.

The game could get a sequel given how the story goes, and I hope it does. I'd buy the sequel if it also has more great metal songs. Although if they went for a less brutal metal direction I'd also be interested. There's a lot of metal subgenres that could fit a siege to [spoiler] heaven. [/spoiler]

131350350.review:
Alright, I don't normally do any reviews for games, but this game is fantastic, even if short.

I am going to start with what I think describes the game: Imagine the game singing and playing your rage and using it as fuel to slay the demons of hell. The more in tune you are with the music the more fuel you are rewarded with. Not just your damage is boosted, but some things will change about your weapons when you shoot or hit in time. 

now that my cringey explanation is out of the way i'm going to share my Pros:
Ascetically the game is one of the most interesting I've seen in a long time, it transitions to different levels of hell that are all different from the last, and each one has its own theme, as well as its own song. Some aspects of the environment will interact with your modifier, the higher the modifier the more spectacular it seems to be. you will see stuff like the torches pulse in time with the music, or those sparklers you would see at a metal concert go off all around the map.

The voice of the narrator is awesome, the lines are witty at times, and are as smooth as butter to listen to, I wish that he would talk more.

The enemies all have a different feel to them, but are all equally as bad-ass as the next one, and each bring something to the fight, and sort of compliment each other when it comes to making your life as difficult as possible sometimes.

The weapons are satisfying to use, and each one is unique. They each have a weakness, that can be made up for by another one.

The cons I have experienced:
I am having difficulty finding anything I dislike about this game.

131283126.review:
Demos are made to give you just a taste of what to expect in the full game, however, Metal Hellsinger is that rare case where it got me hooked to it since its demo. I've spent hours on that demo, even more hours on the gamepass release and here I am still playing it on Steam. 

The soundtrack is amazing, every hell has it's own song sung by different singers and it makes you want to play better as it adds more instruments and vocals as you kill demons.

Movement is great overall but sometimes you'll find situations where hitting a wall after soaring will leave you stuck there for a few seconds which can cause you to die quickly; some objects can also cause you to get stuck.

The weapons are just okay, there are six each with their own ultimate ability but you can't carry more than four and you can only choose two of those since you're always carrying Paz and Terminus.

You have some enemy variety, some that can melee you, others that just shoot, some will cast more enemies to attack you and other will make poison clouds with their shots. There are elite variants for some of these enemies that can be really challenging to kill.

The boss fights can be disappointing, it's always the same boss with some new attacks and the same song, the final boss is quite different, it's straight up bullet hell.

The story is fine, you're mostly here to kill demons to the rhythm.

It's a short game, with just eight levels, but it feels like it's enough, if you want to keep playing there are leaderboards, coats to farm in each level and difficulty to unlock weapon skins and even the Archdevil difficulty unlocked after beating the game in Beast, it makes every level like a Master Level from Doom Eternal and, something that I didn't like much, gives enemies more health.

Devs are adding more content to the game, teasers are being shared on social media.

I love this game and it's music, I can't wait to see what they're preparing for the future.

EDIT: The Dream of the Beast dlc was released and it adds a new weapon called The Red Right Hand, three skins with special abilities for Unknown and two new songs. Its content is alright but since it's cheap it's worth it. 

Leviathan deserved an entire level.

131234471.review:
Imagine Doom 2016, but you have to shoot to the beat of Metal. Yup, thats it.

Metal: Hellsinger has enough variety to keep you interested in its short 4h campaign. Different demons to fight with different skills pop up every new stage save from the last ones. As you progress new weapons are prompted to help you fight the hoard, ranging from classic dual-pistols and shotgun to hellish throwing knives and a devil-balista. 

Everything is themed accordingly and stages are exceptionally pretty for a fast paced game in which you'll find detail if you stop and look around (albeit not the purpose of the game). Soundtrack is Metal, as expected! Songs were created specifically for the game with the help of famous metal vocalists and each stage has its own track with boss fights sharing the same similar theme except for the last one, that goes out with a banger.

Story is clearly not the main focus here and no character shines through more than Paz, which also is not superb.

All in all its only true flaw is that Metal: Hellsinger is short. A 4h experience that leaves you wanting for more due to how engaging it is. Here is hoping a sequel follows, because it is definitely deserving of one.

131231081.review: One of the best soundtracks in a game for sure! Playtime around ~5h for one playthrough.

131231036.review:
I absolutely love the vocalists they brought in for the features. Each is incredibly distinct and adds a metric F^@K ton to the soundtrack.

[b] BUT [/b], I have one gripe and one suggestion with the music, plus one gripe for game play.

Music Gripe: The tempo can be a bit tedious after a while. For the most part, the BPM of each track is pretty similar, + a few for the Aspects and the double time of the Sword's ultimate ability. A bit more diversity in the tracks speed would be much appreciated in any DLC/Sequel. I understand that you wanna keep the core mechanics, i.e. the BPM, semi-consistent throughout the game, but it shouldn't be too much to expect that a player can handle faster/different speeds as the game progresses. 

Music Suggestion: Imma be real, while I really do love the vocalists brought in, they're just not enough. The atmosphere of this game is LITERALLY Hell. There exists no place more evil, horrific, terrifying and brutal. As such, the music should reflect the environment. How? Bring in some Deathcore vocalists. [u]I'm talking Dickie Allen, I'm talking Ben Duer, I'm talking Will Ramos, I'm talking Kyle Anderson[/u]; all these dudes/ a ton of Deathcore musicians are massive nerds and would certainly love to have a hand in something like this. Sure, I understand, the vast majority of metal fans may not appreciate it as much as a Serj or Matt, but perhaps allow other vocalists to produce "covers" of certain tracks and release them as DLC. That's one DLC pack I'd buy in a heartbeat.

Game play Suggestion: I gotta say, while its necessary for clean gameplay, I wish we had more options for beats to hit other than beats 1 and 3 of a bar. Especially in [spoiler] the final track with Serj [/spoiler], it took every fiber of my being not to click along to the 3:4 patterns of the track, as deviating from the 1/3 template would result in lower scores. I'd love if song-specific subdivisions were perhaps included as additional beats to hit. I know it could confuse some and would necessitate more work, but I feel the value added and the incentive it would create to implement more diverse tracks far outweighs any drawbacks.

131224364.review:
I love this game! I think it's a lot of fun to play to the beat. Especially as a musician (and a metalhead) - it combines gaming and music in such a fun way. I love the songs, too! They are excellent. 

If you're having video/sound syncing problems, remember that you can adjust that in the settings. I was having a little bit of problems with syncing at first, and it turned out I was trying to sync it up wrong. I would also recommend just doing a general play-through of a round first to see if your device is syncing the audio and visuals up with your actions on its own. (I ended up over-adjusting in the beginning.)

I have a difficult time with the Mactera flying bugs, the ones that spit at you, so if anyone has any advice let me know! I do like that you can change game difficulties. It helps me to not feel as overwhelmed and get practice in on a lower difficulty, if needed. 

Overall, I'd say it's worth the money and I think it's a lot of fun. You can always wait until it goes on sale, too. AND there's a free demo, which I appreciated, because it gave me the chance to try out the game to see if I liked it before investing my money into it. (Though I kinda figured from the trailers that I would like it anyway.)

131145098.review:
A rhythm FPS game. aka "Doom but you need to have a sense of rhythm".
It's like being in a game trailer. But it's the entire game.

Shooting on beat to the music is required to do any real damage, doing it for long enough and you build a "fury meter" to do even more damage.
It sound simple but it ain't at higher difficulty, with more enemies and stuff to dodge while staying on beat. You also got different combos to do to gain more fury. All of this adding to your final score to the leaderboard.
You got different weapons (Dual guns, Shotgun, Sword, etc) all different to use, and upgrades to fit how you want to play.

The music is of course way above most other games... Well, if you like Metal, that is.
If you do, you got pretty high ranking singers, and the music composition itself is pretty great.
And the better you do in game, the more hardcore the music goes.

The story is pretty straightforward, but with a little twist. 
The voice cast is as good as the music (Jennifer Hale and Troy Baker), good choices there too.

Overall the game can be short if you only expect to play once. But it's pretty much expected that you do play it more than once, with the leaderboard and higher difficulty.

Now that isnt accounting for the other difficulties nor the challenge levels but thats all optional stuff. Its really fun and worth the price but dont expect to sink 1000 hours into it.

I want to love this game so badly, but no matter what I do to calibrate it the beats just don't work properly for me. Rhythm games are my bread and butter, but nothing I do seems to line the visuals up with the audio in this case, which is a shame because the mechanics at play would be perfect if it would just sync up. I've done my best to research this issue to no avail. Most threads just explain how to calibrate at all, rather than the most effective approach to calibrating. I've tried sitting and down and messing with the settings manually and through the quick calibration of the game, and I tried waiting to see if maybe an update would address my issue. Alas, I'm forced to leave a negative review for what's probably an incredible game. The music, the visuals, and the plot have all clearly had a good amount of care put into them, but it's far too tedious for me to see those things through when I can't get the game to function as intended. 

I'm running a 4K 144HZ HDR Monitor with a Ryzen 9 and MSI 3080 12 Gb for reference
